greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of positive integer solutions to the equation |2^x - 3^y| = n.
comment: Pillai (1931) proved that a(n) is finite for all n.
Hershfeld (1936) computed a(n) for n <= 10 and proved that a(n) <= 2 for all large n.
Stroeker and Tijdeman (1982) proved that a(n) <= 2 for all n > 13.
For additional comments, references, and links, see the crossrefs.
a(n) <= 1 except for n=1, 5, 7, 13, 23:  see e,g, Bennett (2003). - _Robert Israel_, Mar 06 2017
reference: S. Pillai, On the inequality 0 < a^x - b^y <= n, Journal Indian Math. Soc., 19 (1931), 1-11.
R. J. Stroeker and R. Tijdeman, Diophantine equations, Computational methods in number theory, Part 2, Math. Cent. Tracts, 155 (1982), 321-369.
link: M. A. Bennett, On Some Exponential Equations of S. S. Pillai, Canad. J. Math. 53 (2001), 897-922.
M. A. Bennett, Pillai’s conjecture revisited, J. Number Theory, 98 (2003) 228-235.
A. Herschfeld, The equation 2^x - 3^y = d, Bull. Amer. Math. Soc., 42 (1936), 231-234.
M. Waldschmidt, Perfect Powers: Pillai's works and their developments, arXiv:0908.4031 [math.NT], 2009.
mathematica: Clear[seq]; seq[m_] := seq[m] = (Clear[a]; a[_] = 0; Do[n = Abs[2^x - 3^y]; a[n] = a[n] + 1, {x, 1, m}, {y, 1, m}]; Table[a[n], {n, 0, 10}]); seq[m = 1]; While[seq[m] != seq[m - 1], m = 2*m]; A219551 = seq[m] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Dec 13 2012 *)
results.author: _Jonathan Sondow_, Dec 09 2012
